conclusion: When the light source moves downward, the angle of incidence of the light changes, affecting both the position and size of the shadows cast by the objects.
As the light source moves downward, the direction of the light rays becomes more perpendicular to the surface of the objects, causing the shadows to shift closer to the base of the objects.
With the light source closer to the objects, the shadows become larger because the light rays are more spread out when the source is lower.
Shadow A (from the ice cream cone) moves closer to the base of the cone and becomes larger.
Shadow B (from the typewriter) moves closer to the base of the typewriter and becomes larger.
Shadow C (from the ball) moves closer to the base of the ball and becomes larger.
Shadow D (from the cylindrical object) moves closer to the base of the cylindrical object and becomes larger.
If the light source moves downward, shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects and increase in size.
